title: 108_s1633
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Notification and Credit Restoration Act of 2003". Congress finds that the privacy and financial security of individuals are increasingly at risk due to the widespread collection of personal information by both the private and public sector. Credit card transactions, real estate records, consumer surveys, credit reports, and Internet websites are all sources of personal information for identity thieves. Identity theft is one of the fastest-growing crimes in the United States, posing a major law enforcement challenge. Criminals use stolen personal information to open fraudulent credit card accounts, write bad checks, and commit other financial crimes. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported being victims of identity theft to the Federal Trade Commission. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported being victims of identity theft to the Federal Trade Commission. Identity theft is costly to consumers and the marketplace. Victims are required to contact various law enforcement agencies, credit reporting agencies, and creditors over many years. The government and financial institutions have a shared responsibility to protect consumer information from identity thieves. The private sector can improve consumer protection by enhancing customer notification and implementing effective fraud prevention measures. The private sector can better protect consumers by improving customer notification, implementing effective fraud alerts, affording greater consumer access to credit reports, and establishing other financial identity theft prevention measures. SEC. 3. TIMELY NOTIFICATION OF UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS TO PERSONAL INFORMATION. Amendment to the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act requires notification to customers of unauthorized access to personal information. In this section, a breach is defined as the unauthorized acquisition of data compromising the security of personal information held by a financial institution. Personal information of a customer includes their first name or initial, last name, and certain data elements like social security number or driver's license number when unencrypted. The breach notification requirements for financial institutions include notifying affected customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement agencies in case of a breach of personal information. This information includes social security numbers, driver's license numbers, credit card numbers, and other sensitive data elements. Financial institutions must notify affected customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement agencies in case of a breach of personal information. Any entity holding personal information for a financial institution must promptly inform the institution of any breaches. Notification must be made promptly upon discovery of the breach and in accordance with law enforcement needs. Financial institutions must promptly notify customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement of any breaches of personal information. Notification should be made without delay, taking into account law enforcement needs and the integrity of the information security system. Delays in notification for law enforcement purposes are allowed if it would impede a criminal investigation. Notifications can be provided to customers in writing or electronically. Financial institutions must notify customers of breaches promptly, in writing or electronically. If notification costs are prohibitive, or contact information is insufficient, email notification may be used. Financial institutions must notify customers of breaches promptly, using e-mail, website postings, media notifications, or other forms as prescribed by the Federal Trade Commission. Additionally, they must inform consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement agencies as directed by the FTC. Financial institutions must promptly notify customers of breaches through various means as prescribed by the Federal Trade Commission. Notifications must also be sent to consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement agencies as directed by the FTC, including specific information in the notification to customers as outlined by the FTC. Compliance with these notification requirements is necessary for financial institutions. Financial institutions must establish a comprehensive information security program to comply with notification requirements in case of a breach. Customers can take legal action for damages resulting from violations of this section. Civil penalties for violations of this section include the ability for customers to seek damages and for actions of financial institutions to be enjoined. The rights and remedies under this section are in addition to those available under other laws. Compliance with this section by financial institutions does not violate laws prohibiting the disclosure of financial information, except as specifically provided. The section specifies that financial institutions are not required to disclose information prohibited by law and do not have new recordkeeping obligations. SEC. 4. INCLUSION OF FRAUD ALERTS IN CONSUMER CREDIT REPORTS. Section 605 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a definition of fraud alerts, which notify users of a consumer's credit report about potential identity theft and unauthorized credit issuance. Consumer reporting agencies must include a fraud alert in a consumer's file promptly upon receiving notification from a financial institution or upon the consumer's request. Express preauthorization from the consumer is required through designated telephone numbers or other reasonable means of communication. Consumer reporting agencies must include a fraud alert in a consumer's file promptly upon request, with evidence of identity theft. They are responsible for informing anyone accessing the consumer's credit information about the fraud alert. The Federal Trade Commission will establish regulations for the duration of fraud alerts. The Federal Trade Commission will issue regulations regarding the duration of fraud alerts and procedures for their removal from consumer files. Consumer reporting agencies and users of consumer reports must comply with fraud alert notifications to avoid violations. The text chunk discusses the consequences for users of consumer reports who fail to comply with fraud alert procedures, including issuing credit to the wrong person. It also prohibits taking adverse actions against consumers solely based on the presence of a fraud alert in their file. Access to credit reports and scores is addressed in Section 5. Section 612(c) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with no-cost access to credit reports and scores. Consumers can request disclosures once a year and every 3 months during a fraud alert period. Credit reporting agencies can charge a fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with free access to credit reports and scores. Credit scores are now included in the reporting, as required by the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the Federal Trade Commission, in consultation with other financial regulatory agencies, must issue final regulations to implement the Act's amendments.
